Award.AwardTitle: The roles of chemotaxis-like signal transduction systems in the differentiation and behavior of motile filaments of the cyanobacterium Nostoc punctiforme
Award.AbstractNarration:
The price of motility in cyanobacteria of the genus Nostoc is the transient differentiation of non-growing filaments called hormogonia. Hormogonia function as active dispersal units, allowing the organisms to exploit a favorable, or escape an inhospitable, habitat. Hormogonia of Nostoc punctiforme are phototactic, as well as chemotactic to exudates of plant partners, with which N. punctiforme forms a nitrogen-fixing symbiotic association. One long-term research goal is to manipulate hormogonium differentiation and behavior in experiments to establish new nitrogen-fixing associations with crop plants.

The genome of N. punctiforme contains five loci of genes that encode proteins of chemotaxis-like signal transduction complexes. Among these five loci, one locus is essential for the differentiation of hormogonia and another for phototaxis. The involvement of a chemotaxis-like signal transduction system in regulation of cellular differentiation has precedence, but is rare. A variety of experimental approaches will be used to characterize the chemotaxis-like developmental regulation locus (Che2) and the phototaxis locus (Che4), including mutational analysis to determine the functional requirement for the gene products in each locus, DNA microarrays to identify genes under control of the Che2 locus, and bacterial two hybrid assays and mass spectrometric analyses to identy protein-protein associations in assembly of the signal transduction complexes. The results of these collective experiments will provide information on how the signal transduction complexes are differently organized and localized in cells, and how they may have evolved into different functional roles, especially in the regulation of development.

The emerging database will be essential for subsequent manipulation of these symbiotic cyanobacteria for agricultural or bioenergy applications. The project will develop experimental tools and materials that will be immediately available to the scientific community. A graduate student and visiting student will be trained in functional genomics. Two to three undergraduate students will trained each year in microbial genomics, genetics and biochemistry by their participation in short-term, well-defined, undergraduate research projects.

Overview. The cyanobacterium Nostoc punctiforme typically grows as a straight chain of cells (a filament).  Nostoc species and other related filamentous cyanobacteria can fix nitrogen (reduce N2 gas to ammonia). Nostoc punctiforme is unique in fixing nitrogen in both a free-living and a non-crop plant-associated, symbiotic growth state.  The Nostoc needs to move in order to infect the plant partner. To gain motility, Nostoc must differentiate into a transient, specialized non-growing hormogonium filament. Production of motile hormogonia is a normal part of the life cycle of Nostoc and typically about 10% of the filaments in a culture are in the hormogonium cycle. When the plant partner is starved for combined nitrogen, it produces chemical signals into the environment that stimulate Nostoc to differentiate essentially 100% of its vegetative filaments into hormogonia. We call this plant factor a hormogonium-inducing factor (HIF). The hormogonia become motile by an unknown gliding mechanism about 12 hours after receiving the plant inducing signal and maintain motility for about 48 to 60 hours; they then complete the hormogonium cycle by reentry into the vegetative growth state. The 36 to 48 hour motile state reflects the infection window for establishment of the symbiotic growth state, wherein the Nostoc supplies all of the nitrogen needs for growth of the plant partner. The long term goal of my research program is establish a knowledge base that we can use to design experiments to manipulate crop plants to form a nitrogen-fixing symbiotic association with Nostoc. Such associations would provide biologically fixed nitrogen directly where needed in agricultural systems, reduce the energy demands for chemical synthesis and application of nitrogen fertilizers, and minimize nitrogen enrichment of watersheds that lead to algal and bacterial blooms in surface waters.

 

Objectives. The immediate goals of this project are to characterize a signaling system that previous genetic experiments indicated influences the gliding motility of hormogonia. The signaling system is analogous to four proteins identified as controlling the directing of swimming in response to chemical nutrient concentrations in many bacteria and referred to as a chemotaxis signal transduction system. The experimental approaches were first to construct targeted gene mutations and document the behavior of hormogonium filaments; biochemical assays to follow the transfer of phosphate from one protein to another in the signal transduction system; and microscopic visualization to determine the production and localization of possible motility factors.

 

Results. Mutant analysis indicated two differences compared to the parental organism.  First, the low level of hormogonium filaments typically seen in cultures was absent in mutants and second, when exposed to HIF, essentially 100% of the vegetative filaments differentiated into hormogonia, but the filaments were non-motile. Moreover, the mutant hormogonium filaments lacked an extracellular polysaccharide present in the parental.
